awd_titl_txt: The Biophysics of Collective Cell Locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
For a single fertilized egg cell to form into an embryo, there are many intermediate steps, including repeated cell division and development of organs in the correct location. But the details of this process and its regulation have yet to emerge. For example, in the sea squirt -- a simpler system than the human embryo but one that shares a lot of commonalities -- a pair of cells is the starting point of the heart of this organism. These cells must move from their origin to the future location of the heart guided by cues from inside the embryo. As the paired cells move, they must push other cells out of their path to reach their destination, all while not losing contact with each other. Although observational studies of the coordinated movement of groups of cells involved in organ formation advance knowledge of embryonic development and associated congenital conditions, this project will deepen understanding by employing mathematical modeling and computer simulations to tease out the many facets of this process. The project will involve developing new computer simulation schemes for the mechanical interactions between cell boundary and interior dynamics, new models for the biochemistry needed to initiate collective migration, new methods for efficiently solving equations in deforming, moving geometries, and extensions to full three-dimensional domains. The investigators will use the interdisciplinary nature of the project to recruit and train undergraduate and graduate students. 

The study of collective locomotion of organisms has led to important mathematical models that have guided biological discovery. A distinguishing feature of this project is that the multi-body interaction is achieved through mechanochemical bonds that interact with the cell's biochemistry and biomechanics in an unknown way. We focus on the collective migration of two cells in the early stages of heart development of the sea squirt Ciona intestinalis, an important model organism. Initially, these two cells are indistinguishable, yet at some point they establish leader and follower roles and move with distinct morphologies, squeezing through deformable tissues. Experiments show there is an advantage to move as a cohesive pair rather than a single cell, however, it is unclear why two cells do not slow each other down. These observations lead to the following questions: How are intracellular mechanics integrated to give rise to motility as a cohesive group? Why can two cells move faster together than alone? Is the two-cell system better at polarization and initiating migration than an individual cell? Mathematical modeling can aid experiments in answering these questions, but numerical solutions of the model equations will require development of novel computational methods that will be able to simulate coupled mechanical, transport, and chemical reaction equations in complex evolving geometries. Collaboration with an experimental lab will result in the discovery of a set of minimal yet sufficient interactions underlying the mechanical and biochemical organization of a cohesive cell group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded research project has made significant technical innovations in the field of mathematical biology and provided several novel insights into biological systems. We have been tackling the question of how do small groups of cells move together? This process—called collective cell migration—is critical to things like wound healing and embryonic development. The funding has allowed our group to become a leader in developing theoretical frameworks for behavior, coordination, and motility dynamics of small cell groups.

By developing new mathematical models and computer simulations, we have discovered how cells communicate, coordinate, and move as a team. These models give us a powerful, low-cost way to test ideas that would be much harder to study in the lab alone. A few highlights from our work include: (1) development of new algorithms to simulate how cells form patterns and networks, and how tightly they stick together while moving, (2) detailed biomechanical models of how just two cells move as a pair—something that turns out to be surprisingly complex, and (3) applications of cutting-edge method called topological data analysis to study the shapes and connections of cell groups as they form. 

One of our most exciting discoveries came from a project led by an undergraduate student. Using our models, we identified what is biochemically regulated at the junction between neighboring cells to ensure that a group of cells move in the same direction. This is an important finding — an example, cohesiveness of cell group movement ensures that a wound heals or that cardiopharyngeal progenitor cells form the heart in the correct location within the organism. In this work, mathematics represented an inexpensive way to test which molecules are needed and how their kinetic rates are modulated at the region of cell-to-cell contact. 

Another breakthrough came from a postdoctoral researcher on our team. We compared two types of cells: epithelial cells, which line surfaces like your skin, and neutrophils, a kind of white blood cell. We found that epithelial cells prefer to move as a tightly connected unit -- almost like one giant cell -- while neutrophils move more independently. Our math models explained why: epithelial cells reduce how much they stick to their surroundings, allowing them to better transmit force from one cell to the next. 

Beyond the science, this project has supported the training of 6 students -- 4 undergraduates, a graduate student, and a postdoctoral researcher. They’ve learned programming, computer simulations, mathematical modeling, and data analysis, and all have presented their work at major scientific conferences. We’re proud that 5 of the 6 have gone on to STEM careers in government, industry, or academia. We’re committed to keeping our work open and accessible. All of our papers are freely available through platforms like arXiv and bioRxiv, and our simulation tools are shared on GitHub and Zenodo. To date, our research has led to over 10 publications and was recently featured in Northeastern University’s newsletters. We also wrote a key review paper that summarizes what’s currently known about how cell groups move.

In short: this project is showing how mathematics can help us understand the hidden choreography of cell migration -- and how that knowledge might one day help us heal better, grow organs, or even fight disease.
